content.question: One end of a string of negligible mass is wrapped around a pulley and the other end is connected to a hanging block of mass <math alttext="m " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math>. A motor exerts a torque of magnitude <math alttext="tau" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>τ</mi></math> on the pulley and causes it to rotate in the clockwise direction, lifting the block. The radius of the pulley is <math alttext="R" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>R</mi></math> and the rotational inertia of the pulley is <math alttext="l" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math>. Which of the following equations accurately represents this scenario and could be used to solve for the angular acceleration <math alttext="alpha" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>α</mi></math> of the pulley?

choices.label: <math alttext="tau minus m, open parenthesis, alpha R minus g, close parenthesis, R, equals l alpha" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>τ</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>m</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>α</mi><mi>R</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mi>R</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>I</mi><mi>α</mi></math>

<math alttext="tau minus m, open parenthesis, alpha R plus g, close parenthesis, R, equals l alpha" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>τ</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>m</mi><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>α</mi><mi>R</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mi>R</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>I</mi><mi>α</mi></math>

<math alttext="tau minus m alpha R squared equals l alpha" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>τ</mi><mo>−</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>α</mi><msup><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mi>I</mi><mi>α</mi></math>

<math alttext="tau plus m alpha R squared equals l alpha" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>τ</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>α</mi><msup><mi>R</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mi>I</mi><mi>α</mi></math>
